abstract.p: Dr Albert S Kirsch letter on July 3 article holds climate change resulting from rising carbon dioxide levels are easily predictable

block.p: Predicting climate change is admittedly difficult and controversial (''Efforts to Predict Effects of Global Warming''). It seems almost like attempting to predict stock prices based on previous performance. But we can at least estimate future conditions based on CO2 levels, which are increasing at roughly 1 percent annually, from about 300 parts per million, typical of prior interglacial warm periods, to 360 today and to 500 by 2100, even if we do everything ''right.''

Predicting climate change is admittedly difficult and controversial (''Efforts to Predict Effects of Global Warming''). It seems almost like attempting to predict stock prices based on previous performance. But we can at least estimate future conditions based on CO2 levels, which are increasing at roughly 1 percent annually, from about 300 parts per million, typical of prior interglacial warm periods, to 360 today and to 500 by 2100, even if we do everything ''right.''

What are controversial are the possibilities spun out by various models. They depend on the assumptions used and on computing power. But you don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind is blowing when CO2 levels vastly exceed any in the past 400,000 years. Advice: Don't buy oceanfront property for your grandchildren.
DR. ALBERT S. KIRSCH Bal Harbour, Fla.
